On april 4, 2012
Azmael
This is both chit-chat and suggestion thread.


So im finding myself quite surprised that after the HUGE success of the 1st Clash no thread was really made to dish out suggestions and to discuss the event. There was alot of spread around talk . . . especially how survivalists were too favorable to win and etc etc.

Discuss:
So im curious with the obvious CotT 2 coming in season 5 are people going to follow up with the same class choice? Are you going to avenge the loss from this season? Or will you switch things after a dissapointing town?


Suggestions:

More Towns

I think Workshop and Motion Twin were both extreamly unprepared when it came down to the popularity of the event. The massive amounts of players that wished to participate was overwhelming and many felt cheated when they couldnt participate.
So with that being said i think an obvious move for the 2nd Clash would be to once the original 6 towns are full to try and fill some extra towns.

Clash of the Titans is a competition between classes not towns so if we have 6 or 12 or 20 towns it wont damage the integrity of the contenst since we are trying to find out who the true master class is. And with more towns we can have more broader ranking of the powers of each class.


The survivalists got ALOT of smack talk during and especially after the CotT 1 was done. Everybody was saying how the class was too favorable to win and that there wasnt much of a surprise there.
I agree the class had good start but i think people are overrating the power of the class.
People and organisation always will beat classes!!! Thats how d2n works. The game has alot of random and luck factors and survivalists managed theirs the best they could and won.

With that being said after all the smack talk and for the sake of lore i think it will make some kind of sense if the 1st Clash Champions re-group to "defend" the title in the CotT:2.
Maybe its because the movie just came out i dont know but we could dub the second clash as

CotT2: Wrath Of The Titans

Wrath reffering to the anger of the winning team and eagerness to defend the title. Obviously it might not be easy to get everybody from the original team but i reckon if at least 20 of those players are in the same town it could be counted as the champions defending.




So yeah share with us fond memories of the first clash and give us your ideas about what the 2nd Clash should have and how the event can be improved.

Quent
@Azmael
I know Survs had good organisation.
But this is a necessary condition to win. Is it also a sufficient condition?

If the guardians had won COTT 1 everyone would be SURPRISED. Nobody would say guardians are better than other classes. Everyone would say they had great organisation + enough luck to beat survs.

Come on! Before the Clash most of the people were putting their bets on survs FOR A REASON!

But let's assume for a moment that each town does exactly the same equally good, with no random dramas and no accidents.

Lets even ignore the fact that all towns can lose people due to camping for blueprints on early days
Oh, sorry. Almost all towns.

So, we have each town alive and well on day 16.
Survs were well organised, others were well organised + lucky during camping for blueprints. Fine.

Now, lets say all towns can defend day 16 (tamers had lots of stuff to dump, guardians huge def boost etc) and they go camping on day 17, while survs go camping on day 16.

Who wins the clash? You tell me.
Hint: One town won't lose anyone during the first 2 or 3 days of camping.

Current scoring system favors survivalists, it's not a theory, it's a fact!
On april 4, 2012
Azmael
Very true! I agree with you Quent.

BUT Die2Nite in its nature is a very very very random luck game. There soooooooooooo many things that can go wrong. You can almost say that there no 2 towns ever the same.

From IRL issues preventing people to log-in to forgotten gates.

The buildings on the map and there location.
BPs that you find.
Wonders do absolutely nothing for a town especially in a cmopetiting town.
Will you get the builds merchant.
How will your attacks be stacked.
How much food/drugs you find.
What kind of weapons you have and how many of them.
Flatpacked Furniture finds.

There so so so many factors that influence the outcome of a town.

Few unlucky attacks or BPs can ruin a town right off the bat. Or maybe the end game attacks get bad spreads are too many players die thus shortening the towns lifespan. . . .


I still agree and support the fact that Survivalists are clear favorites but the advantage in terms of % i wouldnt put it too high when looking at the big picture.
Also some other towns had some minor drama in them thats also an aspect of the game . . .so i think when looking at the big picture even though the survivaists have an advantage it doesnt neccesery guarantee them the N:1 spot.

Also id like to point out that there was a large amount of top tier players who didnt participate in the 1st Clash. So who knows some extra talent in the 2nd one could shake things up quite a bit.

Because 1 year of playing this game and ive learned one thing for sure. Organisational skills are the most important thing. And there some players here in this game that are MAD organisers that can lead to victory any kind of group X_X (well almost)

Suggestion:

What about the last Clash champs having only 1 town while others get 2~4 as it goes down the ranking? Like, taking the first Clash as example:

Survs: 1 town;
Tamers: 2 towns;
Guardians: 2 towns;
Scouts: 3 towns;
Scavs: 3 towns;
Techs: 4 towns;

In case of a new profession added the community could discuss how many towns they could have. My idead on why this? Being the champs means the class must have something to take advantage on others, so less towns are needed on it so others have a more fair chance. The thing is I think Techs will have too much man power and might win taking advantage on numbers. As others assume (me thinks), each town is ranked separately and only the very best of that class takes it to the rankings, and, maybe, a special distinction for being the winner town of their class, except for last champs who'd have only 1 town?

And, before the open sign up goes on, the champs town should be aske if they want to keep the people list of the winner town on the previous Clash, to defend their belt properly, then raffled between themselves 20~25 spots(?). Could as well do the same to other classes, but, maybe, with less spots available(?).

If on this setup, the Survs this time will have to get some extra work done to get ahold of themselves because other classes would not only want to win the Clash but to win their own internal competition as well, you know.

Just my 2 cents, I'll be sure to skip anything on the day of the sign up opening to get my spot on Tamer Town 2 anyway.

I've been in a ruin as a Tamer. It doesn't help that much. It's like the indicator on the game tile that points in the direction of the town.

In a ruin, it indeed tells you the general 'compass' direction the exit is, but it won't tell you if you should go up, or turn right to reach the exit.

Best way is still have the Dusk Dawn Ruin Map open in another window beside your game window, and keep track of where you are as you move.

SinSniperWell, thanks for pointing all these requests in my direction. But I don't want them.

In return you maybe could clarify something on the World Forums for me (I am not a hero right now, so I am lacking writing permissions):

To what other people have said about too many survivalist towns, I think it comes down to whether you consider this a competition between classes or between towns. If it was truly a competition between classes, then yes it'd be better to have fewer survivalists not more. But realistically, we're here to have fun, nobody's really that invested in proving a point about classes, are they? There are major advantages to doing it as it is currently:

-More people get to play the class they want to
-If survivalists really are all that much better, it gives the survivalist players a more competitive experience, since they won't be able to relax and assume they'll do well
-If the survivalists really are all that much beter, it'll give the other classes a more competitive experience because, with three survivalist towns, it's more likely they'll beat at least one of them

That said, with the standard "this is probably going to be awesome and I'm really grateful to the organisers for their efforts no matter what" disclaimer, I would really like to hear from Epoq why there won't be a shaman town. I remember him saying it a while ago, and since then I think there have been a lot of people saying there should be one, and few saying there shouldn't. I'm convinced that they're balanced enough not to be doomed to come first or last, and I don't see what the harm is in opening a town up and seeing how many join. Perhaps it's already too late for that, but why not remove survivalists 3 (which STILL only has 4 people, so it's no big loss) and add shaman 1?

Leapfrog
PerpetualSinI don't really understand why some of you are getting worked up about "requirements" that don't even exist.

The conversation has turned from a requirement complaint to a discussion about whether there should be requirements, what they should be, even what the event is about.

Honestly, I can understand the idea of it being an important, big-league sort of event for proven players. I can also understand where people are coming from in seeking to set requirements on entry. Initially I thought that was the case, and I was willing to accept it, kind of like how I know I can't just walk up and participate in the Olympic Games.

But given that it's not an event which is being micromanaged to ensure maximum success chances (with consideratsions such as distinction requirements, hero unlocks, demonstrated class knowledge and nominations and votes and so on and so forth) I think saying who does or does not deserve to play is something of a mine field. What do you base it on? Sometimes there'll be a clear choice as to whether someone should or shouldn't be included, but the rest of the time it's very hard to judge someone else's merit and experience. Combined with very different ideas about just how the event should operate, it becomes.. something of a topic of discussion.

I would be all for it being a super-serious elites-only event if that had been the commonly-held intent from the start, but I don't really think that's what people want - generally, anyway. For all that we all want to bring glory to our town and our class, I think most of us want to have fun with our fellow players, and the true nature of the event lies somewhere in the middle of the serious/fun curve.

And yeah, CotT shouldn't explicitly be a teaching ground, because that's not really the intent of it - but I don't think there's a problem if less experienced types join and need a little direction, so long as they're willing to learn. They're a better choice than 1500+ SP griefers, or players that are too headstrong to cooperate.

Maybe for Clash 3 we should have a super-serious league and more of a lenient, fun-having league? It'd be interesting to compare the results. Food for thought.

EDIT: Also, I think the Shaman topic is worth revisiting too. I really want there to be a Shaman town!

On june 5, 2012
Wayson

Do we have a start date for Clash 2 yet?

-

Speaking as one of the members of the Clash 1 Surv town, I don't think Survs will win again. One of our big advantages was that we were able to step outside and get 6 more AP while only using 1AP (had to have 1 to step outside, that AP got wiped when we used the book). This let us build every day with minimum 11AP, allowing for more scavengers to go out. With the nerf to Surv book usage, there will be less AP available for building, so I suspect that we'll be seeing more people going out to scavenge and fewer building.

Another huge factor in Surv victory last time was something simple: we had no deaths before we started the camping phase. Just that alone let us build up a lead over the other towns, and this was compounded by the fact that during the camping phase more or all of us remembered to click the 'camp' button. While replicating this again isn't impossible, I consider it... unlikely, particularly in light of how many folks probably picked Surv this time around thinking that it's a guaranteed win.

With the changes to Dumps in S5, I personally believe that Tamers have a good shot at the #1 town. Camping buildings pre-devastation will result in a few losses, but being able to defend a few extra days before starting the camp phase will probably hopefully mitigate this.

I dont think it's class balance that all 10 towns in CotT will get the exact same result if they play exactly the same, on the exact same maps.

Each and every class has their ups and downs. They are good at different things, and the point of it is really not for everyone to be exactly equally "good". First of all it depends on what is considered "good", and of course there are many different opinions on what's "good".

In my opinion the point of having different classes is that they offer different play styles. Someone said scout sucks, and guardians are better. Well guess what, I think guardians are boring as hell, and scout is one of my two favourite styles to play in this game right now.

I dont think Die2Nite intended for the "ultimate town" to have an equal distrubution of all classes, that would be quite boring if you ask me. The fun thing about this game is that you can combine different play styles and game elements with different hero setups in towns to try to reach an "ultimate" result. so i'll stick to my original reason for reading this hot mess... do we have town coordinators selected? and can they be announced? are volunteers needed to help sort things out?

some of us are getting a bit nervous about the organizational details but no one needs to waste epoq's or sinsniper's time by adding to their inboxes. as some have already mentioned, last time workshop had a great group of reliable veteran players acting as pre-game town organizer/coodinators who went over the registration lists and nailed things down once registration had ended (and may glory forever rain upon them for doing such a fine job.) after looking into the fine-grain details of souls in the sign-up lists over the last day, it would soothe my nerves for one if i knew we had reliable individual town coordinators - people actually involved in the game and community - working on making sure we'll have towns full and ready to go more or less on time.

before i accidentally jump-start the "should there be an experience minimum?" debate, let me say my real concern is the numbers of highly inexperienced players (and i am talking players with as little as 1 town under their belts) who seem very likely to have simply not understood the requirement to buy hero days in order to participate, and seem very unlikely to do so at this point. we've heard this lack of understanding directly from a few signed up for in the town i'm in. the numbers of available back-ups in combination with the frankly unreasonably short notice given us all to be available (though personally i've kept myself free for more than a week now and have no desire to put things off) makes it look like an open question as to how many towns will actually fill with paid heroes.

...and dammit, i'm jonesin' to play this thing!

Captain Canada, I think people are giving you a harder time about it because they didn't expect it of you. You kind of expect a random selfish person to show up and be an idiot but you don't expect a good player to throw in the towel like that.

I think everyone should keep in mind that you were very stressed. And yes, you shouldn't have to stay with something that's affecting you that badly.

But I think you should have voiced that. I think you should have said that you didn't want to be stuck in a leadership role and that is was stressing you out terribly, rather than just quit the town and make the situation worse for everyone. And I think you know that.

You came and posted it here in order to vent your frustration and defend yourself, and although that makes you better than someone who quits without a word, it also makes you a target.

I think this will blow over. Tempers are still running high and, honestly, being so defensive about it is probably making things worse. You're hinting that you did the wrong thing but at the same time putting so much into your defense that it doesn't really sound like you regret it.

We know you had reasons for doing what you did. We think you handled it wrongly anyway. But it happens. I think the best thing you can do for your reputation is to stop the defensiveness and just apologize - and mean it, if you can do that - then take a step back and let it heal.

And although I'm sure you wish it would, it won't make things better instantly. People will still be upset, particularly those in your town. But I think it will be the best thing in the long run.
